title: Californias iconic Highway 1 near Big Sur ready reopen
story: The newly built, two-lane stretch of road in Big Sur, California opened on Wednesday - two days ahead of schedule The transportation department posted a photogram on Twitter on Wednesday that showed the new road and said it's now 'OPEN for business'.Construction workers made good progress and officials decided to reopen it ahead of a ribbon-cutting ceremony scheduled for Friday. Big Sur, with miles of rugged coast, cliffs and wilderness about 150 miles south of San Francisco, features spectacular views of the ocean and accommodations at high-end resorts. The slide along the highway linking Northern and Southern California has stymied visitors and hurt businesses, including Ragged Point Inn and Resort, which saw business cut in half.The scenic stretch of Highway 1 in the popular tourist area reopened (left) to traffic more than a year after it was blocked off by a massive landslide (right)    The stretch of scenic highway was buried in up to 40 feet of stone and dirt after the mammoth landslide in May last year (pictured above)          Construction workers made good progress and officials decided to reopen it ahead of a ribbon-cutting ceremony scheduled for Friday          Josh Collins, of Associated Traffic Safety, removes a Road Closed sign from the roadway as Highway 1 is reopenedMum forced to flee with child as carjackers drive off with carWaitress tackles male customer after grabbing her backsideLast known survivor of Amazon tribe captured on cameraBrutal bat attack caught on surveillance video in the BronxShocking video shows mother brutally beating her twin girlsBrexit Secretary Dominic Raab wants to 'heat up' talks with EUIncredible moment cop fires gun through windshield in pursuitBiker jailed after filming himself speeding at 200mphSen. Jeff Flake says Trump gave 'aid and comfort' to PutinDesperate parents queue for hours for school breakfast club placeTrump's daughter grasps her Secret Service agent's handA frail Richard Bacon is spotted leaving hospital with a walker'We are beside ourselves,' resort spokesman Rori Cosma said about the highway reopening. 'We're extremely happy and desperate to hire people.'Cosma said the parking lot was packed Wednesday with drivers circling for a spot. After more than a year of disappointing foreign tourists with news that the highway was closed, he said he was thrilled to tell visitors of the early reopening.Houses toppled, cars washed away and towns swamped with mud:...Share this articleHighway 1 has been dogged by slides since late 2016 but the one that hit Mud Creek near Ragged Point in Big Sur in 2017 was monumental. Millions of tons of earth moved, displacing 75 acres  of land.The slide buried the highway perched on the slope of mountains rising dramatically from the Pacific Ocean.The debris slid well out into the ocean, creating 15 acres  of new coastline about 9 miles  north of the Monterey-San Luis Obispo county line. title: Now Gaucho steakhouses bust 50m debts
story: Argentine steakhouse chain Gaucho has become the latest restaurant group to fail.There  are 1,305 total employees at the group, comprising  the 540 axed Cau staff, 714 at Gaucho restaurants and 51 at its head office.It is thought the firm owed £50million to its banks and faced a seven-figure tax bill.The group, which is backed by private equity firm Equistone, becomes the latest high-profile restaurant group to hit troubles, after Prezzo, Jamie's Italian, Byron and Carluccio's all revealed plans to close outlets this year.FTSE CLOSE: Pound slides to $1.31 as inflation holds steady...Premier Foods boss faces showdown with disgruntled investors...Gaucho steak restaurant chain on brink of collapsing into...Is the pensions dashboard doomed? Rumours Government is...What you need to think about when writing a will: The things...House prices grow at slowest rate since summer 2013,...Share this articleA Gaucho spokesman said last night: 'Despite an extensive process which attracted proposals from a number of parties, it is with regret that, due to the complexities of the group's legal structure, ongoing under-performance at Cau and the level of indebtedness, the directors have been unable to find an agreed, solvent solution.' Matt Smith, joint administrator, commented: 'Unfortunately the Cau brand has struggled in the oversupplied casual dining sector with rapid over-expansion, poor site selection, onerous lease arrangements and a fundamentally poor guest proposition all being factors in its underperformance.' 'As such, the decision has been made to close this loss-making part of the group with immediate effect, unfortunately resulting in today's redundancies.'          There are 1,305 total employees at the group- the 540 axed Cau staff, 714 at Gaucho restaurants and 51 at its head office.'The Gaucho business on the other hand, which operates in the premium dining market, continues to trade well in its market segment, is profitable and has a strong underlying brand and guest loyalty,' Smith continued. 'We are taking steps to stabilise the business following our appointment and are now seeking expressions of interest in terms of a sale of the Gaucho business. We appreciate the support of the group's colleagues and management team and other key stakeholders in achieving this aim.' A spokesman for Equistone said: 'Equistone has been a supportive majority shareholder to Gaucho Group since its investment in 2016, working closely with the company to address the challenges presented by the adverse trading conditions that have negatively impacted the UK casual dining sector as a whole. 'Despite Equistone having presented Gaucho’s lenders with, and committed to funding, a business plan that would have maintained the company as a going concern, a notice of intention to appoint administrators was submitted.'Good for big potsGood for big potsFee back in trades Compare the best investing platform for you

title: Sir Cliff Richard having lunch watched TV horror Algarve raid unfolded flat
story: A very emotional looking Sir Cliff Richard seen leaving the High Court after winning his battle with the BBC. The singer was having lunch at his Algarve retreat in August 2014 when the police raided his luxury apartmentThe ramifications of that dramatic raid on August 14, 2014, are still being felt today. But the sorry saga started two months earlier when BBC reporter Dan Johnson received a tip-off from a confidential source.It was at the height of Operation Yewtree, the extraordinary Metropolitan Police investigation into a string of celebrities following the Jimmy Savile scandal.A junior but ambitious reporter, Mr Johnson said his tipster had revealed there was ‘one more high profile person being investigated’. The reference was oblique, but the journalist guessed correctly it was Sir Cliff. And when the source told Mr Johnson, whose BBC patch is the north of England, that the investigation was ‘closer to home’, he also worked out it involved South Yorkshire Police.Although Mr Johnson never named his source, the court ruled yesterday it was most probably either a police officer from the Yewtree inquiry or someone associated with the police.The reporter was on the trail of what his boss called a ‘bloody cracking’ scoop – but he was described by the judge as ‘capable of letting his enthusiasm for his story get the better of his complete regard for truth’.‘BLACKMAILING’ THE POLICEOn July 9, armed with his sensational tip, Mr Johnson spoke on the phone to South Yorkshire Police’s head of communications, Carrie Goodwin. When he casually asked whether Sir Cliff was ‘on their radar’, she gave ‘an audible gasp’, he told the court.          Police officers search the property of pop star Sir Cliff Richards in Sunningdale, Berkshire in August 2014. Sir Cliff watched the breaking news Miss Goodwin, who had been privately briefed about the highly sensitive investigation by police chiefs, remarked that he had good sources, claimed Mr Johnson.Miss Goodwin told Matthew Fenwick, the detective superintendent leading the investigation, and chief constable David Crompton. The police say they decided to co-operate with the BBC to avoid the story being broadcast and tipping off their suspect before they were ready to swoop on his home.They invited Mr Johnson in for a meeting. At 1pm on July 15, he met Miss Goodwin and Mr Fenwick – and their discussion is hotly contested.The reporter claimed police voluntarily gave him information about their investigation, confirming it involved a 13-year-old boy allegedly sexually assaulted in a dressing room after a Billy Graham event in Sheffield in the 1980s.But the force said Mr Johnson already knew these details and used them to ‘blackmail’ police into giving the BBC advance notice of their raid on Sir Cliff’s apartment.Either way, a deal was struck. Miss Goodwin said the police would give Mr Johnson the date and location of the search if he agreed not to broadcast the information in advance.EXCITEMENT AT THE BBCJubilant that his ‘tactics’ had worked, Mr Johnson told his BBC editor Declan Wilson, who passed it on to his own boss, Gary Smith, with an email entitled: ‘Sit down when you read this.’In reply, Mr Smith quoted from Sir Cliff’s 1968 Eurovision Song Contest entry by saying: ‘Congratulations. And jubilations. I want the world to know I’m happy as can be.’ Mr Wilson claimed police had even considered arresting tennis fan Sir Cliff at Wimbledon, adding: ‘Off record, they want the publicity as they believe there are others.’          A very emotional looking Sir Cliff Richard seen leaving the High Court after winning his battle with the BBC. The judge said: ‘Excitement was being created in the BBC over the prospect of the story.’ When Mr Johnson was asked by his boss how he had managed to persuade the police, he said he had got detectives ‘over a barrel because of the tip-off I had received’.On the evening of August 13, police stuck to their deal and gave the journalist the details he needed. They even emailed him an aerial photo of the apartment block.The BBC machine swung into action. Camera teams were dispatched to the apartment in Berkshire, police HQ in Sheffield, Sir Cliff’s home in the Algarve and his other home in Barbados. And that helicopter was fired up.Mr Smith, the BBC’s UK news editor, wrote in a gleeful email: ‘The money shots will be police going in and out of his flat and loading bags of hard drives or whatever into their vans. We can only get this from the helicopter.’BBC BEAT POLICE TO THE DOOROn the morning of August 14, Operation Kaddie was launched – and hapless police found the BBC were already there.Mr Johnson and two other reporters and their crews had set up camera angles well before 9am, ready to cover the drama live. As the helicopter hovered overhead, a police press officer updated Mr Johnson with text messages.Woman 'saw a black Mercedes like the one owned by Borce...Share this articleIn five cars, eight police officers entered the gated estate at 9.35am. They spoke to a building manager who phoned Sir Cliff in Portugal to tell him police had arrived with a warrant to search his home. Sir Cliff later told how, as a decent, law-abiding citizen, all he thought was that he must help the police and instructed the manager to ‘Please let them in’.Police entered the apartment at 10.40am, and three minutes later Mr Johnson was informed by text.From the camera in the helicopter, officers were filmed going through the singer’s possessions. And on the ground, an officer read a prepared statement to a BBC crew. By now, Sir Cliff’s lawyers had been alerted too and were racing to the scene.A ‘HUDDLE’ IN THE NEWSROOMIn the BBC newsroom at 12.15pm, managers held a ‘huddle’ to discuss their scoop and whether to name Sir Cliff, even though police had not. The go-ahead was given by deputy director of news Fran Unsworth, who considered it ‘strongly’ in the public interest.At 1pm the BBC unveiled its ‘top story this lunchtime’ along with dramatic footage of the police raid.          News helicopter images of police arriving to search the Berkshire property belonging to Sir Cliff Richard in relation to an alleged historical sex offence. The ‘vile’ allegations hung over him for almost two years until the police dropped the case without any charges The broadcast went live to Mr Johnson outside the property, and he continued his breathless reports on the BBC News Channel all afternoon. In total there were 44 BBC TV broadcasts that afternoon, with Sir Cliff’s strenuous denials added to the reports from 2pm.A BBC editor, Richard Clark, sent Mr Johnson a congratulatory email saying: ‘Good work, Dan. Well done.’ The reporter replied it was ‘old-fashioned journalism’.But by the evening, an explosive row was brewing.THE FALLOUTOn Radio 4’s Six O’Clock News, respected home affairs correspondent Danny Shaw suggested the BBC’s tip-off had been an ‘attempt by the police to ensure maximum coverage’ of the raid.South Yorkshire Police responded angrily, saying they had not tipped off Mr Johnson, who had ‘blackmailed’ them. Press chief Miss Goodwin complained to him: ‘This wasn’t the case and brings the force into disrepute.’She wrote to her chief constable: ‘It’s wildly inaccurate. The Met leaked it and we asked the BBC not to run it.’ As police prepared an explosive press release claiming the BBC had been fed the tip by Operation Yewtree, Mr Johnson, knowing his tip-off had come from someone outside South Yorkshire Police, begged his superiors to put out a correction to the Danny Shaw report.

title: Burberry burns 28m excess luxury clothing year
story: Upmarket British fashion label Burberry has destroyed more than £28 million in unwanted products this year, amid a continued downturn in sales it has emerged. Pictured: Suki Waterhouse and Cara Delevingne in a Burberry campaignBurberry, valued at around £9.6 billion by Forbes magazine, admit they burn unsold stock but say they worth with specialist incinerators to harness the energy produced, The Times reports.Luxury brands destroy unwanted products to protect their intellectual property and brand values, insiders suggest. Designer labels, it is claimed, do not want their products to be sold at discount rates elsewhere, or by the 'wrong' type of people on the 'emerging grey market', thus devaluing the brand.Grey markets are where goods are traded unofficially, without having been obtained from the manufacturer or without their consent.  'I do hold him responsible': Trump now claims he told Putin...Share this articleSome analysts suggest higher price points in China and south-east Asia is causing the surplus in stock, with the cheapest ruck sack of offer almost reaching the £1000 mark.Possibly because of this, Chinese executives announced a plan to average four per cent in China last week  The official explanation was that the decision followed a reduction in Chinese import tariffs.  The high-end clothing brand, known for it's £1,450 trench coats and checked design, has seen the value of its waste rise by 50 per cent in two years in a worrying trend. Pictured: Rosie Huntington-Whiteley models for the firmBurberry defended their actions, claiming it is an industry wide practice.But environmentalist have been left angered, while it is not only Burberry who engage in the act. High-street retail giant H&ampM admit to burning unwanted stock to help power Vastera, a small Swedish city.  Burberry defended their actions, claiming it is an industry wide practice. Pictured: Romeo Beckham models the firms clothingWhile Richemont, the company that owns the Cartier and Montblanc brands, had destroyed more than £400 million of watches in two years after buying back unwanted stock from jewelers. Meanwhile, Brits binned £12.5 billion of clothes last year, sending some 300,000 tonnes to landfills. The Burberry firm was formed in Basingstoke, Hants, by Thomas Burberry in 1856. He quickly found the value in famous faces being seen wearing his range, and arranged for Lords Kitchener and Baden-Powell to own his weather-proof coats.The trend continues today, with the likes of Romeo Beckham, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley and Cara Delevingne all fronting campaigns for the fashion house. A Burberry spokesman told MailOnline their brand 'has careful processes in place to minimise the amount of excess stock we produce. 'On the occasions when disposal of products is necessary, we do so in a responsible manner and we continue to seek ways to reduce and revalue our waste. 'This is a core part of our Responsibility strategy to 2022 and we have forged partnerships and committed support to innovative organizations to help reach this goal. 'One example is our partnership with the Ellen MacArthur Foundation’s Make Fashion Circular Initiative, where we join other leading organisations to work towards a circular fashion economy.' Luxury brands like Burberry burning stock worth millions | News | The Times

title: Thai cave boys visit Buddhist temple honour hero Navy SEAL Brit diver flies Bangkok
story: Young footballers rescued from caves in Thailand have started their first day back home by visiting a Buddhist temple - to pay their respects to a er who died trying to save them          The 11 boys and their coach joined their families at the Wat Pra That Doi Wao temple, overlooking Myanmar on Thailand's northern border as they knelt to pray for protection from misfortunes          A portrait was displayed of Saman Gunan, the former Navy SEAL who lost his life while playing his part in the rescue of the Wild Boars team          Pictures have emerged of British er Vern Unsworth (in the orange shirt) - who was instrumental in the rescue operation - at Bangkok International Airport a day after Tesla CEO Elon Musk apologised for calling him 'pedo guy' The billionaire insulted Mr Unsworth on Twitter after Mr Unsworth dismissed Mr Musk's offer to help save the children using a mini-submarine as a 'PR stunt'.Mr Unsworth had said he was considering legal action, while some investors in Mr Musk's company had demanded an apology.Yesterday Mr Musk wrote that 'my words were spoken in anger' after Mr Unsworth said the businessman could 'stick his submarine where it hurts'. A kiss for our hero! Relatives of soccer team trapped in...Elon Musk APOLOGISES to cave er he labelled 'pedo guy',...Trapped Thai soccer team had dug a five-yard TUNNEL in a bid...Share this articleMr Musk added: 'Nonetheless, his actions against me do not justify my actions against him, and for that I apologise'.But Mr Unsworth, who lives in Thailand, told Australia's 7 News: 'It's not finished. I believe he has called me a paedophile.' On Wednesday evening, the boys and coach faced the media for the first time since their ordeal, describing their surprise at seeing two British ers rising from muddy waters in the recesses of the cave. It would be another week before they were pulled out of the Tham Luang cave.'We weren't sure if it was for real,' 14-year-old Adul said. 'So we stopped and listened. And it turned out to be true. I was shocked.'     The team has already said they would ordain as Buddhist novices to honour Gunan. They are pictured kneeling to pray in a temple today          A remaining member of the squad, Adul Sargon, who is not a Buddhist, did not attend the ceremony, which is meant to extend one's life and protect it from dangers          On Wednesday evening, the boys and coach faced the media for the first time since their ordeal, describing their surprise at seeing two British ers rising from muddy waters in the recesses of the cave          Coach Ekkapol Janthawong, second from left, and members of the rescued soccer team enjoy their breakfast before a Buddhist ceremony that is believed to extend the lives of its attendees as well as ridding them of dangers and misfortunes in Mae Sai district, Chiang Rai province, northern Thailand todayIn one poignant and emotional moment at the news conference, a portrait was displayed of  Gunan. One of the boys, 11-year-old Chanin 'Titan' Vibulrungruang, the youngest of the group, covered his eyes as if wiping away a tear.'I feel sad. And another thing is I'm really impressed with Sgt. Sam for sacrificing his life for all 13 Wild Boars to be able to live our lives outside happily and normally,' he said. 'When we found out, everyone was sad. Extremely sad, like we were the cause of this that made the sergeant's family sad and having to face problems.'The Wild Boars had entered the cave on June 23 for what was to be a relaxing excursion after soccer practice. But rain began, and water soon filled the cavern, cutting off their escape, and they huddled on a patch of dry ground deep inside the cave.Coach Ekapol 'Ake' Chanthawong said the trip was meant to last one hour, simply because 'each of us wanted to see what was inside.'          The Wild Boars had entered the cave on June 23 for what was to be a relaxing excursion after soccer practice. Some of the boys are pictured praying at the temple today  Sompong Jaiwong (centre), a member of the rescued soccer team, arrives for a Buddhist ceremony in Mae Sai district, Chiang Rai province today  Members of the rescued soccer team today paid their respects  in front of a portrait of Saman Gunan, the retired Thai SEAL er who died during their rescue attempt          Members of the 'Wild Boars' football team rescued from a cave in northern Thailand prayed for good luck at a Buddhist temple on Thursday morning after spending their first night back home with family          The teammates and coach were discharged from hospital Wednesday after recuperating for a week from their 18-day ordeal inside Tham Luang cave with no food and only rainwater to drinkWhen the hour was up, they were pretty deep inside and already had swum through some flooded areas in the spirit of adventure. But in turning back, he discovered the way was not at all clear, and he swam ahead to scout the route, attaching a rope to himself so the boys could pull him back if necessary.He said he had to be pulled out.Ekapol said he told the boys: 'We cannot go out this way. We have to find another way.'The boys told reporters of their reactions at that point.'I felt scared. I was afraid I wouldn't get to go home and my mom would scold me, said Mongkol Boonpiam, 13, prompting laughter.Ekarat Wongsukchan, 14, said they decided 'to calm ourselves first, to try to fix the problem and find a way out. Be calm and not shocked.'The group had taken no food with them and survived by drinking water that dripped from the cave walls, Ekapol said, adding that all the boys knew how to swim, which had been a concern for rescuers.  Wearing threads of white string tied around their wrists and holding hands together in prayer, the boys sat together in the temple while chants of Buddhist monks (pictured) filled the room.   Soccer coach Ekkapol Janthawong (second from left) and members of the rescued soccer team attend a Buddhist ceremony  Cameras flashed away as the now-famous Wild Boars entered the temple on Thursday, in a sign of the ongoing interest in the story. Film production houses have said they are looking into a Hollywood-style treatment of the harrowing ordeal, which captivated people around the world as the risky operation to extract the team unfoldedTitan said he tried hard not to think about food. 'When I'm starving, I don't think of food otherwise it'd make me more hungry.'Adul said they were digging around the spot when they heard the voices and Ekapol called for silence.He recounted how Ekapol told them to '`quickly get down there, that's the sound of a person, or else they're going to pass on by,' something like that.'But he said his teammate holding the flashlight was scared, so Adul told him 'If you're not going to go, then I'll go.''So I quickly took the flashlight, and quickly went down, and I greeted them, `hello,'' Adul added.Psychologists had vetted the journalists' questions in advance to avoid bringing up any aspects of the rescue that might disturb them. The dangers of the complicated operation, in which the boys were extracted in three separate missions with ing equipment and pulleys through the tight passageways, were not discussed.Doctors said the 13 were physically and mentally healthy. Although they lost an average of 9lbs during the more than two weeks they were trapped in the cave, they have since gained about 6.5lbs on average since their rescue. They were treated for minor infections.Asked what he had learned from their experience, 13-year-old Mongkol Boonpiam said he felt stronger. 'I have more patience, endurance, tolerance,' he said.Adul said it had taught him 'not to live life carelessly.'          After spending a night at home many of the boys attended a ceremony the next morning at Wat Pha That Doi Wao in Mae Sai near the Myanmar border where they prayed for longevity and a good life          They also paid tribute to a former Thai Navy SEAL er Saman Kunan (pictured), who ran out of oxygen and died while helping resupply air tanks along the cave's narrow passageways. He was the only casualty in the otherwise successful operation that was dubbed 'Mission Impossible'           Officials have advised families of the youngsters to avoid interviews with the media for one month to let them settle back into their normal routines          The youngsters walked into the cave on June 23 after football practice, thinking they would only be there for an hour to explore, and then vanished for days until they were finally found          The team spent more than two weeks trapped in the flooded Tham Luang cave before being rescued by an international team of ersWhile many of the boys wanted to be pro soccer players when they grow up, at least four of them said they hope to become navy SEALs, so they could help others.All expressed their apologies to their families.'I wanted to apologize to my parents. I know that I will get yelled at by mom when I get home,' said Pornchai Kamluang, 16.Ekarat said sheepishly he wanted to apologize to his parents because while he told them he was going to a cave, he told them the wrong one.'I told them I was going to Tham Khun Nam,' he said. 'I didn't tell them I went to Tham Luang. So I was wondering how they found us at the right cave.'A remaining member of the squad, Adul Sargon, who is not a Buddhist, did not attend today's ceremony, which is meant to extend one's life and protect it from dangers.

title: Ever wondered happens airbag armchair set off
story: Hold on tight: The man sits in the beige chair ready for take off          The video, filmed in a field in Wayland, Iowa, sees the man shot five feet into the airHe body slumps as the video switches to slow-motion and he is propelled limply into the air.Hilariously, the man maintains a straight face throughout - even when he lands on his backside on the grass.The camera man bursts into uncontrollable laughter while his unfortunate friend looks stunned as he lies on the grass.

title: Jewish cemetery against art gallery nursery students digs win new building year
story: The £6.12 million extension was needed at Bushey Cemetery to provide a further 17,000 grave spaces for the next 50 years after the original 43,000 burial spaces were almost full. The architects, Waugh Thistleton, have delivered a number of new synagogues and have a strong and long-term relationship with the Jewish Community           The cemetery extension is set in 16 acres of landscaped land and contains a mortuary, two prayer halls and offices. Its buildings have taken inspiration from from the Jewish idea of being buried very simply in a cardboard coffin and simple clothes.  They also carry through with the Jewish belief in 'earth to earth, ashes to ashes'          Trees line the cemetery which uses balancing ponds fed by a clever drainage system to capture the increased rainwater runoff. The rammed earth walls of the prayer halls will return to the earth once the cemetery is full              In the two prayer halls, the floor gently slopes and tips visitors forward along the route to the graves. Light floods in from above through large, high windows Judges described Bushey Cemetery, by Waugh Thistleton Architects, as an 'an extraordinary spiritual building formed of natural rammed earth walls, oak and rusted steel, with the beliefs and customs of the Jewish faith at its heart'.They said: 'In keeping with the Jewish idea of being buried very simply, in a cardboard coffin, simple clothes, the buildings carry through the idea of returning the body to the ground, 'earth to earth, ashes to ashes'.'In contrast with the plainness of the buildings, the landscape is almost lush. The limited number of buildings, the simplicity of the forms and expressionist choice of materials all reflect the symbolism of burial to the Jewish community.'           Overlooking the Celtic Sea, the new £20m Tate St Ives opened in October 2017 after a four-year building project.  The gallery now has enough space to accommodate the 250,000 visitors who visit it annually and bring in £11m per year to the local economy           The space to exhibit art has been doubled by adding over 600 square metres of galleries and also led to new studios being created for learning activities.  St Ives is well-known for its art scene and the refurbished and extended gallery can now provide a permanent home to those local artists artists for the first time          The gallery, which overlooks Porthmeor Beach, has been extended and sunk into the cliff behind the original building. The four-storey extension featuring the new gallery has sea views in places Tate St Ives is the most well-known new building on the list.It recently won Art Fund Museum Of The Year, winning a £100,000 prize after opening a new £20 million gallery 'sunk into the cliff'.The four-year building project doubled the space for art at the venue, adding almost 600 square metres of galleries.          New Tate St Ives, Cornwall (Jamie Fobert Architects with Evans And Shalev): 'An ingenious reconfiguration and extension of the postmodern art gallery which doubles the exhibition space, creates a new public walkway connecting the town to the beach and helps St Ives attract a growing number of international visitors.'           Bloomberg London is the new European headquarters of the financial and media company and for the first time, brings all 4,000 London employees together in one building. Designed by Forster and Partners, the nine-storey building cost £1bn with work starting in December 2010            The building is located close to St Paul's Cathedral and the Bank of England, set on a 3.2 acre site which provides around 1.1 million square feet of office spaceRiba president Ben Derbyshire said that half of the six buildings on the shortlist were commissioned by UK universities.He said: 'Each of the projects on this year's shortlist shows the power and payback of investing in quality architecture.'This shortlist illustrates why UK architects and architecture are held in such high regard around the world.'In these challenging and turbulent political times, we must celebrate how the UK's architectural talent can help to improve local communities and their quality of life.'London’s ‘Cheesegrater’ tower, Tate St Ives and a touching...Introducing the Scalpel, the Flower Tower and... the Can of...Revealed: How 4,650 mega-basements have been approved for...Share this article    Bloomberg, London (Foster And Partners): 'A highly-innovative new workplace in the City of London.... which pushes architecture's boundaries and seeks to enhance the neighbouring public realm.'           The Sultan Nazrin Shah Centre of Worcester College which is one of Oxford University's most historic colleges, opened in October 2017. The College needed further teaching facilities to increase capacity             The building makes the most of natural light and high ceilings to make it feel spacious. Oak is used throughout the building to provide decoration and the furniture           Contained within the building is an auditorium, dance studio, seminar rooms which are all accessed from a central foyer           The Sultan Nazrin Shah Centre, Worcester College, Oxford (Niall McLaughlin Architects): 'A floating auditorium crafted from classic Oxford stone and natural oak to blend exquisitely into the established landscape of Worcester College.'           Storey's Fields Centre and Eddington Nursery is situated in the heart of Eddington, the University of Cambridge's new district that lies to the north west of the city. The centre opened in Autumn 2017           Storey's Field Community Centre and Nursery, Cambridge (MUMA): 'A breathtaking building, commissioned by the University, for the new community of north west Cambridge. Inspired by the college cloisters and courts of the City, this project has a sustainability agenda at its core.'           Eddington will become a new sustainable settlement with the Storey's Field Centre and Nursery at the heart of this new community. It is hoped it will be able to host weddings, funerals and music concerts as well as acting as a civic centre          The University of Roehampton's Chadwick House Hall provides 210 en-suite bedrooms for their students across three new buildings. They have been designed around gardens to encourage the students to socialise          Chadwick Hall serves Froebel College and contains 94 en-suite rooms with single beds, 28 premium en-suite rooms with small double beds and 86 premium en-suite rooms with single beds and balconies. An en-suite room for academic year 2018-19 costs £172.50 per week with premium rooms for the same academic year costing £177.80           Chadwick Hall, University of Roehampton, London (Henley Halebrown): 'Three new, intelligent buildings which surround the Grade II-listed Georgian Downshire House and provide high-quality student housing for Roehampton University, built on a modest budget           The halls are located in the grounds of the 18th Century Georgian Villa, Downshire House and next to the London County Council's Alston West Estate. Both are Grade Two listed buildings

title: Dozens BA passengers spend night sleeping FLOOR
story: BA passengers sleep on the floor or in chairs at Heathrow Terminal 5 last night after an IT glitch caused chaos          One victim posted this picture of the queues at Heathrow this morning as people try to get new lights          People say they have been left completed stranded and are unhappy with the level of customer serviceSonja Stokoe tweeted this morning: 'Flight cancelled and stranded at Heathrow last night with 2 kids. Then 2 hours standing in a taxi queue. All airport hotels fully booked. No BA staff could re-book flight to Glasgow for today and now they're all fully booked!! How do I get home???'  @HeathrowRefugee, who posted a photo of BA customers sleeping on the floor,  wrote: 'We are still here in a 4 hr queue to rebook our flights around the world. Your company @British_Airways still has 100s, maybe 1000s stranded. No breakfast. No hotels. No-one to talk to. Information keeps changing. Help!'.British Airways claims that all customers were either offered a hotel room or the chance to pay and claim it back, as long as it didn't cost more than £200. One customer said that the nearest hotel in that price bracket for 20 miles so had no choice to sleep inside Heathrow.'This is shambolic!' Ryanair customers explode with fury...Pensioner who flew into a rage at stewardesses and demanded...'Geez, this is going to be bad?' Terrifying footage from...MP is slammed for telling father of three children killed on...Share this articleA spokesman for the airline said: 'We are doing everything we can to help customers whose travel plans were disrupted yesterday from a supplier system issue affecting a number of airlines, and the temporary closure of Heathrow Airport's air traffic control tower.'The supplier has resolved the issue, our flights are operating today, and we have apologised to our customers for the inconvenience'.BA said other airlines were affected yesterday but rivak Virgin Atlantic said it had no problems  at Heathrow.  The computer failure came just hours after a fire alert at Heathrow's air traffic control tower had forced flights to be erted.Journalist Pauline McKenna wrote on Twitter: 'So @British_Airways, how many flights have you cancelled this evening? Very long, very slow queues of people trying to leave.'Sky News reporter Darren McCaffrey wrote: 'Passengers arriving at Heathrow T5 (I'm one of them) are being told that another computer system failure means NO British Airways flights are taking off. Passengers being told to go and book hotels or seek alternative travel arrangements.'           People were stuck at the airport as departures and arrivals were cancelled following the evacuation of the control tower           Social media is packed with complaints from customers claiming they were badly treated and let down by BAThe airline has struggled with IT problems in recent years.In 2017 a computer meltdown forced British Airways to cancel 726 flights over three days. It left 75,000 passengers stranded and lost the company around £100million.British Airways introduced its new FLY IT system in 2017 But at the time one source said it crashes 'all the time' and claimed check-in staff have been reduced to tears by regular glitches. Union leaders also said that BA staff say FLY 'is not fit for purpose'. A survey by GMB of 700 staff in June 2017 found that 89 per cent said training was poor, 94 cent suffered delays or system failures and 76 per cent said their health had suffered because of stress or anger aimed at them by frustrated passengers.The software is designed to help with  every aspect of a passenger's check-in, from the seats they are allocated and the baggage they are allowed to bring on.It is also believed to handle the checking of documents such as passports - or photo ID for UK flights - as well as visas for countries including the US - and the issuing of boarding passes to mobile phones. But desk staff are said to have complained about a so-called 'doughnut of doom' which can appear when they try to work through the system.And as they wait for the system to catch up queues form in front of them, which only gets worse if the system crashes completely.          Aircraft are pictured stationary at the scene yesterday after a fire alarm cancelled departures and evacuations          Chaos in the skies: London's Heathrow Airport closed to arrivals and departures and evacuated its control tower todaySome staff are said to be completely stressed out by the check-in software and even cry on the way to work because they fear what will happen if there are more problems.  BA is run by parent company IAG after it merged with Spanish giant Iberia in 2011. Heathrow Airport is one of the busiest transport hubs in the world with flights landing on the tarmac every 90 seconds on average.Although the lockdown lasted only around an hour, it is likely that thousands of journeys will have been affected as passengers missed connecting flights or were barred from taking off altogether.   Summer holiday travel chaos as Ryanair cancels 600 flights over cabin crew strike in Belgium, Portugal and Spain that will affect almost 50,000 passengers Ryanair has cancelled up to 600 flights over two days next week because of a strike by cabin crew.Workers in Belgium, Portugal and Spain will walkout on Wednesday July 25 and Thursday July 26 in a move that will affect 50,000 passengers.It is expected to cause chaos for anyone flying to or from those three countries next week and comes days after separate industrial action by Ryanair's Irish based pilots.Cabin crew in Italy are also striking but a spokesman for the airline said this was not expected to affect the 'Italian-based schedule.'          The strike will cause chaos for anyone flying to or from those three countries next week and comes days after separate industrial action by Ryanair's Irish based pilotsThe Irish based airline has apologised for the disruption and said it had contacted the affected passengers, saying that if customers had not already received an email or SMS text, they should expect to travel as scheduled.It said those affected had 'been offered re-accommodation on alternative flights' or a complete refund.However scores of travellers took to social media complaining that there holiday plans had been ruined, and complained they were struggling to get hold of Ryanair to rebook flights.One said: 'Why is it I ring to get some clarity on my CANCELLED flight yet before I can even speak with someone your phone lines hang up on me?!'This is shambolic!! My whole holiday is ruined with 1 week to go to go and I can't get hold of a real person to speak to!!!'Another said: 'Ryanair, cancelled flight due to strike, however can't get in contact with them. No answering of phone, chat, online customer service.'          However scores of travellers took to social media complaining that there holiday plans had been ruined, and complained they were struggling to get hold of Ryanair to rebook flights.Unions in all four countries are asking that Ryanair staff be employed according to the national legislation of the country they operate in, rather than that of Ireland as is currently the case.They also want the airline to give contractors the same work conditions as its own employees.Ryanair's chief marketing officer Kenny Jacobs said in a statement: 'These strikes are entirely unjustified and will achieve nothing other than to disrupt family holidays, and benefit competitor airlines in Belgium, Portugal and Spain.'His statement added: 'Ryanair cabin crew enjoy great pay - up to 40,000 euros (£36,000) p.a. (in countries with high youth unemployment) - industry leading rosters (14 days off each month), great sales commissions, uniform allowances and sick pay.'The European cabin crew strike follows on from separate industrial action by Ryanair's Irish-based pilots.      A tweet posted by Ryanair yesterday announcing the disruption that they said will affect up to 50,000 customers. They also posted a note detailing the conditions its staff work under, calling it 'Ryanair cabin crew - the facts'On Wednesday, the airline confirmed it had to cancel 24 flights between Ireland and the UK, affecting 4,000 passengers, scheduled for tomorrow due to the pilots' strike.The walkout marks the second strike by Irish pilots' union Forsa after it staged a 24 hour walk out last week.Thirty Ryanair flights were cancelled last Thursday, affecting some 5,000 passengers, after the pilots staged their first strike over pay and their conditions of employment.After Friday's strike a third 24-hour walk-out is planned for next Tuesday.The airline, which is Europe's biggest budget carrier averted widespread strikes before last Christmas by deciding to recognise trade unions for the first time in its 32-year history, but has since struggled to reach agreement on terms in some countries.Ryanair, which flies in 37 countries and carried 130 million passengers last year, has so far signed agreements with pilots in Italy and Britain, two of its largest markets, but also experienced minor disruption in Germany and Portugal.

title: UK company unveil photos luxury interior worlds largest aircraft look like
story: These newly-released pictures show what the interior of the world's largest aircraft, the Airlander 10, could look like          The aircraft will feature horizon-to-horizon views during flight. Hybrid Air Vehicles Limited (HAV) and Design Q, who designed the aircraft, released these pictures yesterday          The Airlander 10 will have private en-suite bedrooms (pictured) and can accommodate up to 18 passengers and crew members for a three-day expedition          A spokesperson for HAV said: 'The Altitude Bar (pictured) will offer drinks with the ultimate view, while 18 guests can enjoy fine dining in the skies'          According to HAV's website, the hull’s aerodynamic shape (pictured) will provide up to 40 per cent of its liftPerfect hideaway: Riverside home which can only be seen from...EXCLUSIVE: Inside the plush London penthouse where tragic...Share this article    The jet is made from Vectran and has no internal structure, meaning the interior can easily be redesigned. It maintains its shape through pressure stabilisation of the helium inside the hull          Stephen McGlennan, the CEO of HAV, said: 'Air travel has become very much about getting from A to B as quickly as possible. What we're offering is a way of making the journey a joy'          The aircraft, which is longer than most single-aisle aircraft such as the A320, can take off and land on any flat surface without a runway          The aircraft can stay in the air up for up to five days, and has a cabin which is 150ft long - longer than most single-aisle aircraft such as the A320          HAV and Design Q will continue to work together on the project, with further announcements expected later this year'Passengers on Airlander will have luxurious private en-suite bedrooms and will be able to enjoy horizon-to-horizon views in the aircraft's extensive Infinity Lounge. The Altitude Bar will offer drinks with the ultimate view, while 18 guests can enjoy fine dining in the skies.'The unusually large  cabin, and the lack of internal structure, means that the aircraft interior is incredible flexible and can include reception areas, on-board catering, and various seating options.Design Q's CEO Howard Guy said: 'My team exploited the opportunity that Airlander 10 presents: we had a huge space to create an experience that makes no compromises. 'This is luxury like you've never known it, with the ability to go anywhere in the world.'HAV and Design Q will continue to work together on the project, with further announcements expected later this year.Design Q's CEO Howard Guy added: 'We love doing different things. Our fantastic team of young designers relish the opportunity to do something no one's done before, to imagine a new concept and then to get into the detailed design of what this space will be.'

story: The England goalkeeper has just splashed out on this five-bedroom mansion in Cheshire as he prepares to move in with his childhood sweetheart, Megan Davison, following the Three Lions' most successful World Cup campaign in 28 years           The home in Cheshire features this cinema as well as its own Jacuzzi and takes in views of a nearby golf course while also boasting astroturf garden           Jordan Pickford will move into this plush mansion after he is said to have proposed to his childhood sweetheart, University of Sunderland graduate Megan Davison, while they were on holiday in Barbados Moment Jordan Pickford's girlfriend realised her dreams were...Share this article    The Cheshire mansion was purchased for £1.2million as Jordan Pickford looks ahead to the Premier League season after helping take England through to the semi-finals in the World Cup          Jordan Pickford kisses Megan Davison in the stands at the World Cup in Russia, which was England's most successful in 28 years as they almost made it to the final The purchase surfaced just two months after Jordan is believed to have asked Megan to marry him while they were on holiday in Barbados.University of Sunderland graduate Megan is believed to have been with her fiance since she was 14 years old, when they met at school.
