title: second brexit vote was always the remainers game plan we must not let it happen
story: After two years rubbishing referendums they want another one, a replay.The “facts” have changed, they shriek. Except they haven’t. Theresa May’s proposal to the EU isn’t the grim “reality” of Brexit. It is merely what happens when negotiated ineptly, by Remainers.They further argue we should choose between no-deal, Mrs May’s proposal or staying in. Why? The first vote determined we were leaving. The only reasonable choice would be deal or no deal.But we must not let it happen. Politics is in a dire enough state. The Tories are in meltdown trying to secure Brexit while fending off Corbyn’s Marxists and the nightmarish ruin they would unleash.Overturning the 2016 referendum result before it had even been carried out would collapse all faith in democracy itself.THERE’S no way of sugar-coating it — police just can’t be bothered investigating burglaries, along with much else.We’ve heard all the excuses: they’re hard to solve, we’re too short-staffed, “Tory cuts” and so on.But victim ­Izabela Siergiej gave them the criminal’s name, address and mugshot. And they still judged it too tricky.Last year in the West Midlands burglary was up 11 per cent. Guess why.On so-called “low-level” crime, some forces have shamefully just surrendered.WHY was France’s President Macron buddying up to Putin at the World Cup final?We don’t begrudge him his moment of glory, of course. His team deservedly won. But Putin’s regime is guilty of ­heinous crimes, from the Salisbury poisonings to the downing of a jumbo jet.Four months ago France expelled four Russian diplomats. Was it just a stunt?This wasn’t a summit for world peace, as Donald Trump’s was yesterday. It was a football jolly, sealing a month-long PR triumph for the Kremlin.Macron should have watched from Paris.TAKING back control of our borders won’t mean a thing if we fail to exercise it.It is worrying that immigration has gone up again thanks to a 13-year high in those arriving from outside the EU — which the Government CAN limit.For years the totals have been too great for our communities to cope with. Where are the new homes, hospitals or transport for the 280,000 net migrants in 2017?We’re all for immigration to benefit our economy. But the numbers are nowhere near manageable.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: it was repugnant to watch remainers in commons pm has seen off treacherous bid by labour
story: The vote to stay in a customs union with the EU would have been a fatal blow to Brexit, the Government and the Tory Party. It would have kept us shackled to Brussels’ rules for all time, with no say over any of them.All the ambition for our great country as a newly independent global trader would have been swept away. We would have all the possible short-term pain of leaving, with no long-term gain.Theresa May’s Chequers plan is a feeble Brexit, but at least it’s freedom of a sort. That cannot be said of a customs union.It was repugnant to watch Westminster’s Remainer elite line up to argue for tying us to the EU, and pretend the Leave verdict didn’t mean actually leaving.Many seemed to treat it like a game, oblivious to the terrible danger they would have unleashed had they won.For once, and however briefly, the Government has something to celebrate.OF all the attempts to thwart Brexit, the campaign to pretend the referendum wasn’t fair is the most pathetic and dishonest.The Electoral Commission’s probe into Vote Leave’s alleged overspending is fatally flawed if it failed even to interview those who ran it.Worse, it has not applied the same scrutiny to the Remain camp, which clearly co-ordinated smaller groups just as Vote Leave is said to have done.As for Remainers claiming this alleged overspend skewed a tight referendum, what cobblers. The Commission’s own figures show Remain vastly outspent Leave — on top of the £9million David Cameron wasted leafleting every home begging us to vote to stay in.The odds were massively stacked against Leave and they still won.This Remain rearguard action has nothing to do with the vote’s legitimacy.It is just a continuing tantrum, aimed at the 17.4million who disagreed with them.IMAGINE the outrage if a newspaper hosted online videos of kids being abused.Facebook does, and refuses to remove them. It just marks them “disturbing” and limits them to users claiming to be over 18. Virtually everyone, in other words.A moderator, sickeningly, tells an undercover reporter: “If you start censoring too much, people lose interest in the platform. It’s all about making money.”Since Facebook apparently now considers itself a publisher it must be treated as such. New Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright must continue Matt Hancock’s commendably tough moves towards regulating social media.If Facebook ever had a moral compass it has lost it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may brexit claire foges
story: In 1893 plucky little Texan Jack Burke climbed into the ring to become champion of the American South.The match lasted 110 rounds and seven hours before the ref ended it — Burke had broken all the bones in his hands and was half dead but still carried on fighting.Theresa May is the political equivalent of that fighter: Determined, stubborn — but completely insane to carry on.The Prime Minister is permanently on the ropes. Blow after blow rains down on her authority. She is battered and bruised by her own party yet refuses to realise her time is up.The past few days have brought yet more resignations. Following the Foreign Secretary and the Brexit Secretary are ministers whose names escape me let’s call them Cuthbert, Dibble and Grubb.Though hardly well known, these MPs have grandly flounced off in protest at May’s handling of Brexit.In a particularly odd development, one is leaving the Government because he thinks the Government is not sticking to the spirit of government policy.All this on top of last week’s embarrassment, courtesy of Donald Trump. The President might have softened his comments about the Prime Minister and the “turmoil” afflicting the UK but the damage to May’s authority was done.God knows how this looks to the rest of the world. We used to bestride the international stage like a colossus now we stumble across it like Frank Spencer.The Prime Minister can’t take all the blame. She has been dealt a difficult hand — her party and the country split on Brexit, Europe turning the thumbscrews and Ukip waiting in the wings to hoover up Tory votes. It would be hard for any politician to make an outright success of this.But where Theresa May HAS failed categorically is on communicating her plans to the British people.The Chequers deal should have been a big moment. She should have been all over the TV stations selling this deal hard.In the past, prime ministers held public broadcasts to explain important matters to the people. Anthony Eden gave one on the Suez crisis, Harold Wilson on the devaluation of the Pound. Ted Heath warned in 1973 that the nation faced “the hardest Christmas that we have known since the war”.These leaders looked the nation in the eye, spoke directly to the British people — and LED.Theresa May, on the other hand, seems reluctant to get out and make the case for her own policy.Little wonder that two thirds of the public questioned on the Chequers deal were baffled by it. Confusion reigns.This points to a major problem with May’s premiership. She is hopeless at telling a national story.It’s the job of a leader not just to make decisions but to inspire the nation. For the person in No10, their words speak as loudly as their actions. They need to tell a compelling story about where Britain is going.Margaret Thatcher told the story of Britain emerging from the ashes of socialism thanks to the hard work and enterprise of its people: “A get-up-and-go instead of a sit-back-and-wait-for- it Britain.”Tony Blair told the story of Britain shrugging off the past and embracing the modern world: “A new Britain . . . a model 21st-century nation, based not on privilege, class or background, but on the equal worth of all.”David Cameron told the story of Britain clearing up the economic mess left by Labour, paying down our debts and living within our means.Love or loathe these leaders, at least they told a clear story about where Britain was going. We get none of this from May.She makes a virtue of just “getting on with the job”. But in a nation divided on Brexit, we desperately need more. We need a clear sense of direction for Britain’s future.Of course, the Prime Minister cannot last for much longer. In boxing terms she’s in the 12th round. Before long there will be a leadership contest — and those hoping to succeed May must learn from where she went wrong.The next resident of No10 must not only have the right policies but the right vision.If Britain is to regain its reputation abroad, and its self-respect at home, we urgently need a Prime Minister who inspires, who tells a national story — and who truly leads.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: thousands of brits set to get up to 10k extra after bungling officials screw up benefits payments
story: Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey announced her department will have to pay out millions more to make up for previous errors.The extra cash will go to disabled claimants who were switched from Incapacity Benefit to Employment and Support Allowance between 2011 and 2014.An estimated 70,000 people are eligible for compensation of up to £10,000, with the average payout likely to be around £5,000.The DWP already faced a bill of £340million for claimants who lost out because of the departments mistakes from October 2014 onwards.Now the scheme is being extended as far back as 2011 following a scathing report from the Public Accounts Committee.The report found ESA claimants had been routinely underpaid after switching to the benefit.Hours after it was published, Ms McVey pledged to take further action to ensure that no disabled Brits miss out on what they should have received.She said: I hope this will help members to provide reassurance to their constituents who think they may have been affected that they will receive all the money they are entitled to.But campaigning MP Frank Field warned that ESA claimants had still been denied other benefits such as free school meals, dentists bills and NHS prescriptions.He said: The department failed to listen to claimants, charities and even its own staff when they sounded the alarm.Their warnings fell on deaf ears, and tens of thousands of people lost out as a result. The Government must now learn the lessons from this catastrophic failure as it faces the challenges of migration onto Universal Credit.The DWP will pay out the money over the coming months.

title: heatwave health alert temperature
story: The old, very young and sick risk heat-related ailments as it warms up again from Thursday.Dr Thomas Waite of Public Health England warned: “Temperatures are likely to rise on Friday, through the weekend and potentially into next week.“Older people, the young and those with long-term conditions such as heart and lung diseases may struggle to adapt.“Keep out of the sun from 11am-3pm, walk in shade and use sunscreen. Wear a hat if you go out in heat and carry water when travelling.”Satellite images on Wednesday showed how our longest heatwave since 1976 has turned most of Britain’s green swathes brown in two months.The Met Office said Friday’s 30C (86F) highs would come after thunderstorms in the South and South East and rain in the North.Expert Sarah Kent said: “It will be increasingly warm over the weekend, with very warm if not hot conditions next week.“By the start of next week we could see temperatures climbing to 33C (91F), mainly in the South and South East.”This summer will be among the ten warmest and driest even if it returns to normal. If it stays above average the season could be record-breaking, the Met Office said.The six weeks to July 16 saw average daily maximums of 20.9C (69.6F), just below 1976’s record 21C (69.8F).Highs topped 28C (82F) for 16 days running and on June 28 hit a 33C (91.4F) year’s best in Porthmadog, North Wales.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may should go home
story: They did so by a huge margin. Sadly, a year or so later they also voted to keep the appalling Anna Soubry as their local MP. Let’s hope they never make that mistake again.For the last year this bilious, jabbering woman has done everything she possibly can to thwart the will of her electors.She is a staunch Remainer and is seemingly prepared to bring down the Government to get her way. Her actions suggest she couldn’t give a monkey’s about what the people in her constituency think.Two nights ago she was one of 12 Conservative rebels who voted against the Government. She wanted Britain to remain part of a customs union with the EU. That would mean — effectively — no real Brexit. And if they had won, it would have been catastrophe for the Government. And in my opinion, the country.The reason they didn’t lose is solely down to a bunch of courageous Labour MPs, including the excellent Frank Field, who voted with the Government. Soubry isn’t alone, of course. The people of Loughborough, Leics, also voted by a large margin to leave the EU.But they are represented in the House of Commons by Nicky Morgan, who appears not to give a toss what they think. She also voted for a customs union. Nicky is famous among many for being the second worst Education Secretary this country has ever had. She’s pipped to the post for that particular prize by Justine Greening.Being useless in their Cabinet posts isn’t the only thing that unites these two women. Greening is also opposed to Brexit and she has even called for a second referendum. Because she didn’t like the result of the first one.The people of Beaconsfield, Bucks, voted to leave the EU. But their MP, the grim Dominic Grieve, who resembles a funeral director from about 1923, appears not to care less. He has said he’s prepared to “collapse” the Government if he does not get his way.Sarah Wollaston is another one. Another embittered MP. Her constituency, Totnes in Devon, voted to leave by a sizeable margin.Because while it is true that the majority of Labour MPs are also opposed to Brexit, they have been nothing like as dangerous as the Tory rebels.We are in a mess. The Prime Minister staggers from crisis to crisis, striking meaningless deals whenever she can to stave off defeat for a few more days.She surely cannot last much longer. A Remainer herself, of course, I think she should be persuaded to call it a day. Go home, put her feet up. And let her party elect a leader who will take no more c**p from Brussels.And no more c**p from the likes of Soubry and Greening, either.THE top scientist Richard Dawkins – Britain’s most famous atheist – has got himself into trouble.He has said that he prefers to hear the sound of cathedral bells to the muezzin wail calling Muslims to prayer.  Saying something as inoffensive as that is enough to get you into hot water these days.Dawkins has been called a bigot as a consequence. I have to say I disagree with him. I love the sound of cathedral bells, sure.But I also enjoying hearing the Muslim call to prayer – when I’ve been on my travels in Morocco or Malaysia. But, over here, it’s cathedral bells for me every time.Here’s a tip, then.Take them to an expensive shoe shop and make them look at the display through the window.And remember the noise they make.KATIE PRICE is on holiday in Thailand and of course she’s got her baps out.  This might be a problem for Katie, pictured with boyfriend Kris Boyson.Topless sunbathing is against the law over there. This is because tourists enjoy looking at the scenic islands. Without having their view obliterated by a pair of breasts the size of Koh Samui.So watch yourself, Katie. And as a break from lying on the beach, how do you fancy a spot of caving?YOU’VE got to love the toffs, haven’t you?  Most of them are absolutely crazy after years of inbreeding.Take the brilliant Lizzie Purbrick who described herself as “a very well-bred toff”.  She went round to her married lover’s home after he’d cheated on her with a third woman.No messing with Lizzie. She took with her eight litres of pig’s blood which she sprayed across his flat. She daubed the words “slut” and “whore” and “big d**k lord” on his walls and sprayed a giant penis on the floor.  She said: “So many people have said I should write my life story, but I’m so bonkers I can’t remember it.”The judge said – in one of the great under-statements of the decade – that she had “real concerns about the defendant’s ability to make rational decisions”.No s**t, Sherlock.It started out a few years back with just a couple of stalls. Now the entire town centre is closed off and thousands turn up to pig themselves on cuisine from scores of nationalities.I got so stuffed last year I needed to be helped home. And not a chicken parmo – the supposed Teesside dish of choice – in sight.IT’S not often that the Labour peer Dame Margaret Hodge says something worth repeating. But in telling her party leader Jeremy Corbyn that he was a “f***ing anti-Semite and a racist” I think she kinda hit the nail on the head.Meanwhile, the decent, moderate Labour MP John Woodcock has resigned the party whip and become an independent.Long-time party members – like I was, until last year – know that Labour is currently led by a hard-left anti-Jewish rabble of thickoes.I hope the voters twig this sooner or later.AND now it’s time for Hypocrites of the Week. A special award for Pimlico Plumbers of London.They’ve put up a giant banner outside their premises about Brexit, saying: “Nobody voted to be poorer!”Pimlico Plumbers has just lost a landmark case brought by one of its employees. He, like almost all of their staff, was kept on a contract which allowed the firm to pay him less than the proper rate.They were done under a UK Supreme Court decision, using laws designed to stop unscrupulous firms exploiting cheap labour.I wonder what it is about the EU that Pimlico Plumbers likes so much? Can you take a guess?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: tesco delivery driver autistic toddler viral
story: Lauren Browne, 24, had her weekly shop delivered on Monday and her three-year-old son Tommy answered the door.The youngster didn’t respond to the supermarket worker who asked Tommy: “Are you not up for talking today wee man?”Lauren, from Andover, Hants, then explained that he has autism and expected to receive one of the usual responses, which includes a nod of the head or “bless him”.However, she was surprised when the “wonderful gentleman” treated him no differently and began giving him light items from the shopping to put away.Once all of the products had been stored and Lauren had signed for the order, the man then asked Tommy to sign for the delivery as well and helped him click the “finished” button.Lauren, a mum-of-two, said: “I could instantly see that he was a nice person. It was a really sweet moment.“He treated Tommy like a normal person and no different to before he knew he had autism.“He wasn’t shocked by it which was really nice. It was lovely for him to be included.“A lot of people don’t really understand it [autism] but he was really lovely.“It was quite nice to watch. We don’t really see a lot of people interacting with Tommy on that level.“I just hope that everybody with additional needs can be accepted for who they are and that more people learn how such a simple gesture can really mean so much to somebody.”Lauren was overwhelmed by the caring man and rang Tommy’s dad, Dan Matthews, 24, immediately after and they decided to use social media to try and pass on their thanks to this mystery person.She added: “When people learn about his autism, they tend to shy away from it and talk to me instead but I appreciate it can be difficult for people.“I don’t think a lot of people are educated in autism. It isn’t really spoken about.”Later that day, Lauren wrote in a Facebook post: “I just wanted to give this lovely man some recognition.“Instead of then ignoring him or being awkward about the news he had just learnt, he found an alternative way to communicate with him and that really means the world to me.“Im sure other parents with children who have additional needs will truly appreciate this too.“Unfortunately I didnt get his name but Mr Delivery Driver, if you see this, we thank you so much for your kindness.”The Facebook post has since received 8.6K likes and Lauren says she has spoken with the Tesco customer service team and was told her gratitude would be passed onto the delivery driver.- Autism is a lifelong developmental disability and a spectrum condition that affects how people perceive the world and interact with others.- Autistic people see, hear and feel the world differently to other people.Some say that the world feels overwhelming which can cause them significant anxiety.- Even though autistic people share certain struggles it can affect them in different ways. Relating to other people and understanding others can be a struggle as well as taking part in everyday social, family and school activities.- There are a variety of different levels of support a person with autism may need depending on whether they have learning disabilities, mental health issues or other conditions.- There are around 700,000 autistic people in the UK.- In order to be diagnosed with autism, a person will usually show signs of difficulties with social communication, social interaction and show restricted and repetitive patterns of behaviours, activities or interests from a young age, which may ‘limit and impair everyday functioning’. Tommy was officially diagnosed with autism in January this year after his parents began noticing his slow development and lack of communication.They have been told he currently has the mental age of an 18-month-old child.Tesco has been contacted for comment.

title: cadbury is launching a low calorie dairy milk choc bar and weve tasted it
story: To avoid a backlash, Cadbury will sell the new version alongside the normal one for the same price, currently 60p for the standard 45g bar.But the low-sugar version won’t actually go on sale until next summer while the firm works out how to produce it on a mass scale.Other food and drinks firms who have simply launched a lower-sugar version have been criticised by customers.Cadburys Europe boss Glenn Caton said a team of 20 scientists and choc experts have been working for two years on a way to keep the taste and cut sugar – while using no artificial sweeteners, colours or preservatives.They have reformulated the bar by replacing some of the sugar with a type of fibre that has the same structure.‘I’m expecting the worst from latest Cadbury offering, a Dairy Milk with 30 per cent less sugar.As I put the chocolate in my mouth I prepare to pull a disgusted face but instead I’m pleasantly surprised as it hits my tongue.It has virtually the same familiar indulgent creamy taste of a traditional Dairy Milk bar. Although so it should, seeing as it has been years in the making.But there is one big difference to the original I know and love. The texture is much thicker.The traditional bar is so smooth, it almost instantly melts on your tongue and slides down your throat without needing to swallow. This reduced-sugar offering doesn’t.This one melts and then oozes over your tongue, giving it a heavy chocolatey coating that stays put until you swallow.Even after swallowing there is a little bit of sticky remnant left on my tongue.It’s this tiny bit of clagginess in the texture that tells me this bar hasn’t quite managed the perfect imitation of the fully-sugared original.But to be honest - if you are not as obsessed with chocolate as I am, you probably won’t notice the difference.’This way they can use less sugar but keep the texture – which experts pinpoint as a key feature of chocolate – the same.This is a different method to the one used Nestle which has lead the way in sugar reduction. They have altered the structure of sugar molecules to contain air which means they can use less of the product but the tongue senses the same level of sweetness.In early 2017, Nestle began launching lower sugar versions of treats, starting with KitKat and then Aero and Smarties.Sugar in chocolate varies but milk chocolate is typically around 50 per cent, white around 60 per cent and dark below 40 per cent and as low as zero.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronation street director grooming claims
story: Dowd, 65, was arrested at his £500,000 home in February after police posed as an underage girl in an online forum.He is due to appear before Leeds magistrates next month accused of four charges of inciting a child into sexual activity.He joined Corrie 24 years ago but left earlier this year after his contract was not renewed.Dowd has also worked on Emmerdale, Casualty and Heartbeat. He has directed nearly 200 Corrie episodes since 1994, according to his LinkedIn page.West Yorkshire Police confirmed the summons “in relation to online child grooming offences”.In November, Corrie’s Bruno Langley, 34, admitted sexually assaulting two women on a night out.He was fired from the ITV soap.In 2013 Michael Le Vell, who plays Kevin Webster, faced allegations he sexually assaulted a young girl, but was cleared after a trial.Andrew Lancel, Corrie factory boss Frank Foster, was also acquitted of sex abuse allegations against a teenage boy that year.A year later, 85-year-old Bill Roache, who plays Ken Barlow, was acquitted of historic sex offences against women. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: irish pm plane ban brexit revenge
story: In a Brexit strop, Irish PM Leo Varadkar said it would be a response to Theresa May cutting Irish fishermen’s access to our waters.The extreme action would be a tit for tat punishment for the Theresa May cutting Irish fishermen’s access to our waters.But as a furious row erupted between London and Dublin, UK diplomatic sources pointed out that Mr Varadkar has got his facts wrong - and dubbed his claim “pretty foolish”.The row threatened to overshadow Theresa May’s 24 hour visit to Northern Ireland, which began last night, to sell her Chequers plan for a softer Brexit.Highlighting the importance of keeping the Irish border open, the PM will step up her challenge on hard Brexiteers today (FRI) to stop dealing with the EU exit in high theory and “make a success of it in practice”.Mr Varadkar lashed out while taking his Cabinet on an away day to step up planning for no deal. He said: “The situation at the moment is that the UK is part of the single European sky.“If they leave the EU they are not, and that does mean if there was a no-deal hard Brexit next March, the planes would not fly and Britain would be an island in many ways. If they want their planes to fly over our skies, they would need to take that into account.”The Ireland boss insisted: “You can’t have your cake and eat it. You can’t take back your waters and then expect to take back other people’s sky”.A DExEU spokesman said: “We do not want or expect a no deal scenario. Our White Paper sets out both our desire to agree a mechanism for annual negotiations on access to waters and fishing opportunities, as well as reciprocal liberalised aviation access with the EU through an Air Transport Agreement.”But a senior UK government source branded the comments “mad”.British officials pointed out that freedoms of the air are not guaranteed by the EU, but a multilateral international treaty – the International Air Services Transit Agreement - signed from 1944 onwards, by 133 countries.The only way Ireland can block British planes flying over it would be to pull out of the treaty, which it has been a signatory to since 1957. Others said Britain could retaliate by blocking Irish planes from flying to mainland Europe over the UK, doubling the length of their journies.The Director of the Open Europe think tank Henry Newman said Mr Varadkar is “in danger of losing the plot”.Alex Macheras, Aviation Analyst, said “It’s a ridiculous statement and the reason why ICAO’s International Air Services Transit Agreement exists - of which Ireland are signatory - which ensures countries cannot simply ‘impose a ban’ on their airspace, and the treaty specifically states that countries are forbidden from discriminating against the nationality of an aircraft.“Ireland has very little airspace and if a ban were to take place Ireland would lose all flights operated to/from the country flown by aircraft with G- registrations, Great Britain. This is without mentioning that much of Ireland’s airspace management, and air traffic control, is actually based in the UK.”Brexiteer MP Jacob Rees-Mogg told The Sun: Air traffic control continued between Russia and the Ukraine after Russia invaded the Crimea so this idea is just silly.On the other hand most flights from the EU to America pass through our air traffic control so this rather lightweight Irish gentleman is proposing an absurd act of a masochistic nature. His words are those of an airhead.Andrew Rossindell MP said: Who will this benefit? Mr Varadka needs to think very long and hard before he makes statements like this. Its incredibly damaging to British-Irish relations and very short-sighted. If he thinks this would benefit Ireland, he needs to think again. In reality it would just be catastrophic for everyone.If his ideological obsession with the EU means Ireland cant have sensible relations with its closest neighbour and friend, its a tragedy and totally outrageous. He should stop taking his orders from Brussels and start thinking about the greater good of the people of Ireland and the whole of the British Isles.Ireland will always be tied to Britain, no matter what happens, and if it harms us it will harm them. He needs to change his attitude very urgently.Last night RAF legend John Nichol said: “Regardless of your views on Brexit, the notion that you can have a one way system is farcical and non sensical. It’s a ludicrous notion you can have a ban on civilian aircraft coming to one area but when you desperately need the Brits’ help you change your mind.“That would be strange and incomprehensible. “You really cannot have it both ways. We have spent years building up warm relations with Ireland. They should not be a republic of Brussels and think of their own long-term national interest. The EU will use them and spit them out, but we are genuinely Irelands best friend.Mr Varadka is playing a very dangerous game politically in trying to prevent Brexit.In a second rumpus, Mr Varadkar was also accused of hypocrisy after he claimed the EU had promised him that no physical checks will need to be erected on the Irish border even if the UK crashes out with no deal.Under the “doomsday scenario”, the Taoiseach said the “commitments of others” would then kick in to prevent a hard border. But Brexiteers leaped on his declaration to insist that has been Britian’s argument all along.Tory MEP Dan Hannan said: “Ireland confirms it won’t put up physical border checks in any circumstances, including a no-deal scenario. The UK has said the same from the outset. So what the hell are we arguing about?”Critics also said Mr Varadkar’s declaration was in contravention of the World Trade Organisation’s rules, which insist on borders between different customs regime being policed. Mrs May visited the Irish border town of Belleek in Fermanagh last night to meet local businesses and hear their concerns.This morning, the PM will deliver a speech in Belfast to call on hard Brexiteers who have rejected her softer Brexit Chequers deal to start addressing the reality on the ground. And she will insist that is their “duty”, as the future of the UK is at stake if they don’t.Mrs May will say: “Our job is not to deal with Brexit in theory, but to make a success of it in practice for all of our people. For all of us who care about our country, for all of us who want this Union of nations to thrive, that duty goes to the heart of what it means to be a United Kingdom and what it means to be a government.”But former Brexit minister David Jones challenged the PM to claim the Irish border issue has been “weaponised” by the EU to get its way in the negotiations.During 2017 there was a five per cent increase in the number of flights operating between Europe and the United States which used Irish airspace.They accounted for almost 501,000 of the total number of commercial flights handled in Irish airspace during 2017.Dublin to London is the second-busiest route in world. Almost 4.5million people flew between the Irish and British capitals last year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bargain cafe offers fry up for just one pound and pizza chips and kids meals are a quid too
story: The restaurant chain, called Poundcafé, has also put pizza and chips meals back on the menu in a bid to win customers back.Their decision to re-launch the menu comes as rivals such as easyCoffee continue to grow.According to The Mirror, Poundcafé will be selling the dishes for just £1 in its 10 UK branches from July 30.Customers can select four items from a list of ingredients which includes sausage, bacon, egg, hash brown, baked beans and tomatoes.The four-item dish will cost just £1 but the option to add an additional item will cost 25p.Drinks and desserts cost either 50p or £1 and cakes and gingerbread men will be on offer.Other £1 meals include pizza and chips, cheese on toast, beans on toast, and a pasty.Customers can also buy a sandwiches and sub rolls for £1 and a bowl of chips cost just 50p.Most of Poundcafé’s branches are in the North West of England and in Wales.

title: international driving permits uk drivers brexit
story: Heres what motorists need to know if they wish to take to European roads from next March.If British licences are no longer recognised after the Brexit deal is signed, drivers will be forced to purchase an International Driving Permit (IDP), which would allow them to drive in the EU for up to 12 months.Recommended for around 140 countries worldwide, the IDP is recognised by the 1949 Geneva Convention on Road Traffic and acts as temporary proof of driving ability for travellers.An International Driving Permit isn’t the same as an International Driving Licence (IDL) – which isn’t a legally recognised document.To apply for an IDP you must be over 18 and hold a valid UK driving licence.Currently, British licences are valid in all EU countries, with the Government hoping to continue this mutual-recognition after a Brexit deal is agreed.The Department for Transport has said the prospect of generating up to seven million new permits is entirely deliverable.A government spokesman said: The NAO concludes that the department is making a determined effort to ensure the UK transport system is fully prepared for EU exit and acknowledges that the department has already achieved a great deal.We have prioritised preparation for EU exit and royal assent of the Haulage Permits and Trailer Registration Bill will be a significant step in this process.Available from Post Offices and motoring organisations like the AA, the permit will cost drivers £5.50.IDPs need to be applied for within three months of travelling abroad, and they arent a legally recognised document on their own.Drivers that fail to show both their UK licence and an IDP while overseas could face heavy fines.Members of Parliament have already suggested licences should replace current EU flags with the Union Jack and additional regional banners, while it is likely European branding on number plates will be removed in favour of traditional GB stickers.A spokesman for the Department for Transport told Auto Express: “Our aim is to reach an agreement with the EU for mutual licence recognition after Brexit.Such a deal is in the interests of both sides and we remain confident of reaching such an agreement.“However, it is only sensible that we put contingency measures in place for all scenarios.Ratifying the Vienna Convention (which the UK abides by but has not ratified) will guarantee that UK driving licences will be acceptable throughout the EU when held with the relevant supporting International Driving Permit.”

title: pm victory big six energy price cap

title: how a burglar can crack your home in seconds and how you can stop them
story: Ex home-breaker Michael Fraser has written a four-point guide to ensure your valuables stay safe from thieves.In his guide he has urged people to...He admits to breaking into scores of homes in the past, but has now turned to help people make sure their properties are safe from thieves.Michael said that keeping tools locked away is important as home-breakers will often use spades or shears to prise open doors or windows – rather than smash the glass.He told the Daily Mail: “Most criminals would avoid breaking a window or door panel, as there’s a high risk of cutting yourself and leaving behind traces of DNA, which could lead to their arrest.”For many families a calendar is a crucial part of keeping on top of domestic life, whether it’s the kids’ half-term dates, doctor’s appointments or trips abroad.But Michael said they also offer crooks a golden opportunity to find out when you’ll be leaving your house empty and should be kept out of sight.He said: “Even if the writing is small and the calendar some distance from the window, a determined criminal could zoom in and take a photo of it on their mobile and then enlarge the image for a better view.”While it may seem like a good idea to have a spare key near your porch or front door in case of emergencies – Michael also advises against this.He said that a “high percentage” of burglaries happen when homeowners have had work done, with unscrupulous tradesmen passing on information to thieves.For many people sharing photos on social media is a great way to share memories with friends and family.However, while you’re cherishing the moment – you are also letting thieves know that your house is empty.Michael said: “I would never share my holiday snaps on social media, just as I wouldn’t get a taxi to take me to the airport, tipping off the driver, and anyone else he might know, that I’m away.”

title: ibiza hostel refuses return british tourists passports noisy
story: Stelle Gilchrist, 24, Ford Harris, 24, and Sam Thompson, 19, checked into The Guest House – also known as Villa Armonia – in San Antonio on Monday.The pals, from Farnham in Surrey, say owner Fernando Calduch has demanded the eye-watering sum because of a noisy complaint.Speaking exclusively to The Sun Online, Stelle said: The hostel owner has been so unprofessional and is trying to make a quick dime.The group are supposed to fly back to the UK at 10.30pm but say Fernando has swiped their passports.And Sam relies on taking prescribed anxiety medication on a daily basis.The teenager has not been able to take the vital medication since Monday and the group are extremely concerned for his wellbeing.Stelle said Sam has lost his head not being on it and is really down.Stelle admits one night the gang were particularly noisy but they had apologised profusely to Fernando.Seizing passports and important medication belonging to a hotel guest to extort money from them – despite the earlier dispute – is highly illegal according to Spanish law.When The Sun Online contacted Fernando he confirmed that he did indeed run the hostel and was aware of the dispute.When presented with the allegations that he had stolen belongings from the group he laughed and then told us that he didn’t know what we were talking about before hanging up the phone.The group has contacted the Spanish police and British consulate in Palma to see if they can help with the return of their belongings today.

title: bitter ferocious debate who gets to be a woman
story: Initially, no one on either side was prepared to speak to us - scared of repercussions and reticent about being misrepresented in such a polarised debate.Many transgender people refused to go on record alongside the feminist campaigners who they say deny their very existence.Jess Bradley, the transgender officer for the National Union of Students, identifies as a non-binary woman and was one of the few trans women prepared to speak on camera.She said her community feels under siege and is subject to abuse, which she says has risen sharply since the debate started."It's a hostile time, trans people are very scared... I know simply by doing this piece of media, I will be hounded on social media, it will have a real material impact on my life," she said."One of the things about the gender recognition debate is it's given licence to anti-trans activists using this is an excuse to debate our existence&#8230 in a way that has felt very violent."It feels extremely painful to have a group of people campaigning against your participation in everyday life.":: Opinion - "We need to combat moral hysteria over gender recognition"   She is talking about the so called gender critical feminists. This is a group of women who are worried that the right to self-identify - essentially ticking a box to become a woman as they see it - is open to abuse, compromising female-only spaces and eroding women's rights.We were shocked at the vitriol expressed online from both sides of this conflict.Dr Nicola Williams is another staunch feminist embroiled in the debate. She warns that a system which allows anyone to self-certify as women would be open to abuse, and that it would amount to an attack on women's rights.But all the trans men and women we spoke to were at pains to stress that for them, there is nothing theoretical about this issue.Far from theory, this is their reality. The misunderstanding and misinformation surrounding the GRA and self-identification makes everyday life even harder for a group of people already subject to prejudice and abuse.They point out that the Equalities Act is the law that allows trans people to use the facilities appropriate to their preferred gender.So for many years trans people have been using changing rooms, toilets and women's services such as rape centres - and there is no evidence to suggest that there has been any problem with this at all.The British Social Attitudes Survey, an annual study of public beliefs carried out by NatCen, gave this year's findings on attitudes to transgender people exclusively to Sky News.In general, the public seem to be liberal with 84% claiming not to be prejudiced at all against trans people.

title: jimmy mizens parents we made a promise to remain positive
story: For instance, being woken by Jimmy noisily crashing through the front door after a night out! story: "Unfortunately the mummies inside were not in the best condition and only the bones remain."Some of the remains had disintegrated because sewage water from a nearby building had leaked into the sarcophagus through a small crack in one of the sides.The sarcophagus was accidentally discovered after an ancient tomb dating back to the Ptolemaic period was uncovered during construction work last week. title: mps just voted keep corruption
story: NewsMPs just voted to keep corruption and sex harassment investigations into MPs secretThe list of MPs currently under investigation has already vanished from Parliament's website just minutes after today's decision in the House of Commons&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter16:09, 19 JUL 2018Updated16:46, 19 JUL 2018NewsStandards Commissioner probes into MPs will now be secret until they are concluded (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCurrent corruption and sex harassment probes into MPs will be kept secret after a landmark vote by MPs today. The list of MPs currently under investigation has already vanished from Parliament's website just minutes after today's decision in the House of Commons. It comes after MPs agreed the Parliamentary Standards Commissioner will no longer name MPs it is investigating - until that investigation finishes. Even then, in some cases the MP may not be named, even if they are found to be at fault. The watchdog probes MPs who are accused of using information for financial gain, having a conflict of interest or damaging the reputation and integrity of the House of Commons more generally.  Until this afternoon there was a current inquiries page on Parliament's website, which listed the names of MPs who were subject to ongoing probes. But that page has now vanished after MPs agreed the watchdog should no longer routinely publish information about individual investigations before those investigations are concluded. Backers said the move would ensure consistency and fairness because Parliament's new complaints scheme promises anonymity for both sides.   Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom said: We need a clear run at this, so we need confidentiality and we need consistency. But Green Party leader Caroline Lucas said: I think the optics of this house rolling back transparency is deeply deeply worrying. The proposals were backed by all parties. A direct bid to block the shake-up and keep names public was backed by just 22 MPs - while 79 voted not to block it.  Not a single Tory voted to block the shake-up. Twenty Labour MPs, independent John Woodcock and Green MP Caroline Lucas voted to block it. Seventy of the 79 MPs who voted for anonymity were Tories. Five were from Labour, including shadow equalities minister Dawn Butler. Three were Lib Dems and one was from the DUP . Under the new system, all current investigations by the Commissioner will be secret. If only the Commissioner was involved in an investigation, and not the new system, the MP involved will be named at the end of a probe - no matter what. If both the Commissioner and the new complaints scheme were involved, however, it is more complicated. MPs will not be named if the complaint was not upheld and if they weren't named in the press. Even if the complaint was upheld, the Commissioner will have regard for proportion and the MP's reputation, as well as any desire for anonymity by the complainant, before deciding whether to publish.

story: NewsTheresa May hands top Brexit official bonus of almost £20,000 for “good performance” despite EU deadlockOlly Robbins claimed the payoff on top of his £160,000-a-year salary for his first nine months in charge of the Department for Exiting the EU&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan BloomPolitical reporter22:58, 19 JUL 2018Updated23:00, 19 JUL 2018NewsOlly Robbins is one of at least seven top Dexeu civil servants whose bonuses were revealed (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May handed her top Brexit official a bonus of almost &pound20,000 for “good performance” despite months of deadlock with the EU. Tonight Downing Street insisted Mrs May - who signed off the bonus - thought Mr Robbins was worth it. Mr Robbins is one of at least seven top Dexeu civil servants whose bonuses were revealed in annual accounts. title: tory esther mcvey denies universal
story: NewsTory Esther McVey DENIES Universal Credit has been too brutal - despite revealing yet more climbdowns to comeThe Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is "working on" changes that are "still needed" to the six-in-one welfare system - five years after it launched&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter13:52, 19 JUL 2018Updated14:28, 19 JUL 2018NewsThe Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is working on changes that are still needed to the six-in-one welfare system - five years after it launched (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory welfare chief Esther McVey today flatly denied Universal Credit has been too brutal - despite unveiling yet more climbdowns over the flagship benefit. The Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is working on changes that are still needed to the six-in-one welfare system - five years and a million claimants after it launched. They include more support for the self-employed and possible changes to the taper rate to let people keep more of the money they earn. But she refused to say the system had been flawed - or if she backs ex-welfare chief Iain Duncan Smith's call to pump in &pound2billion a year more. Mr Duncan Smith made his call after money was sucked out of the system before it launched in a move that will leave hundreds of thousands of families worse off. Asked by the Mirror if her climbdowns showed the system as rolled out was too harsh or brutal, she said: It was very very slow as we rolled it out so we were monitoring as we were rolled it out. So no, it wasn't, and we've stopped and changed it as we went along.  What is right is we continue to learn and change. Some &pound1.5billion was put into Universal Credit to make it fairer at last year's Budget, and further cash will be approved for people with severe disabilities. But in May Iain Duncan Smith, who held the job for six years before quitting over one benefit cut too far, called for &pound2billion more a year for UC on top of that. Ms McVey avoided saying whether she backed Mr Duncan Smith. Instead she pointed out the cash that had already been put in. In a speech to charities and campaigners at the Reform think tank, Ms McVey pleaded for their ideas to improve the benefit - despite it being in its sixth year. UC's rollout was blasted by the National Audit Office, pitching her into a public row with the watchdog when she was accused of misrepresenting its findings.  But Ms McVey said: We need to reach out to, learn from organisations such as yourselves, and yes, that includes the National Audit Office, about how to design and implement Universal Credit to support claimants. We want to work with you to understand where we can improve on this important reform. And there are changes that are still needed which I'm working on. Debt repayments, support for the self-employed, payment cycles for those in work, and an extension of outreach work and an extension of flexible support for claimants. Campaigners have warned self-employed workers face being crushed by UC because they are barred from claiming any more benefits than if they earned minimum wage. Ms McVey also signalled she could cut the 'taper rate', the amount of benefit taken away for every pound earned, further after it reduced from 65p to 63p. She said: If we can, yes we would look to reduce that.

title: abbas biggest superfan clives home
story: NewsIs this ABBA's biggest superfan? Clive's home is shrine to supergroup and he even named his daughter AgnethaFor Clive Roe, ABBA has been the name of the game ever since they took the Eurovision Song Contest by storm at Brighton in 1974&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRhian Lubin21:30, 19 JUL 2018NewsAt 71, Clive Roe is still having the time of his life with ABBA's 1976 smash hit Dancing Queen (Image: Ben Lack)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailABBA superfan Clive Roe really does have a song to sing to help him cope with anything. When his mum died, it was the iconic I Have A Dream. When he separated from his wife, the bitter-sweet The Winner Takes It All. And now at 71, Clive is still having the time of his life – with their 1976 smash hit Dancing Queen. Said Clive: “Whenever I feel a bit old and achey, I play Dancing Queen and it makes me feel young again.”  For Clive, ABBA has been the name of the game ever since they took the Eurovision Song Contest by storm at Brighton 44 years ago, in 1974. His living room has become a shrine to the supergroup, with more than 850 pieces of memorabilia lining the walls and filling every shelf. And he even named his daughter, now 33, after his favourite member of the Swedish foursome. He said: “She’s named after Agnetha, though we call her Anna. Agnetha is my favourite – there’s just something about her.”  Explaining how his musical tastes met their Waterloo in 1974, Clive said: “I used to think the Beatles were the best band in the world until I saw ABBA on telly. “I said to my then-wife, ‘They’re going to win it’. She looked at me as if I was mad. They won it by a record score of 24 points.” Each piece of memorabilia makes him feel closer to his heroes – whether it is an ABBA soap bar, keyring or signed album cover. He listens to their music almost daily, has danced through 86 tribute gigs and has been on a TV quiz with the group as his specialist subject. He even took their marital breakups as a model for his own.  Painter and decorator Clive, of Scarborough, North Yorks, said: “I watched for signs of animosity between the couples and there weren’t any. “I realised people can get through a split amicably, and that’s what me and my wife have done. We get along just fine. “Whenever I need a little lift, I look through all my ABBA bits and bobs and it takes me back to happy times. “I see a band at its prime and think of the 70s when things weren’t complicated. “There’s an ABBA song that’s helped me through whatever life’s thrown at me.”  Since forming the group in 1972, Benny, Bjorn, Agnetha and Anni-Frid have sold more than 375 million records and had 19 UK Top10 hits. West End show Mamma Mia!, built around their songs, has been seen by 60 million people worldwide and grossed &pound1.5billion. The film based on the show was a global hit 10 years ago and its sequel, Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again – starring Cher and Meryl Streep – is released today. Single Clive says if a date did not like ABBA, it would be a deal breaker: “I like to bring up ABBA on a first date. “If a lady said they didn’t like them, that would be our last date. It would never work.”  Seeing ABBA live at Wembley in 1979 was one of his highlights. He said: “It was the best night I’ve ever had. “It was electric. I’m a Leeds United fan and I’ve been to winning final matches – this was even better.” After ABBA gave their last performance as a group in 1982, Clive knew just how to cheer himself up. He said: “I played Voulez-Vous or SOS really loudly, shut the curtains and did a little ABBA dance. I felt uplifted. I still do that today. “The music has universal, multi-generational appeal. It’s one reason they’re the best band in history.”

story: NewsAcocks Green mum screamed 'my baby' as carjackers dragged her out of Audi and drove off with newborn girl on backseatClare O'Neill was dragged out of her car and screamed "My baby! My baby!" as the two thugs sped off from the scene in Acocks Green&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter23:38, 19 JUL 2018NewsClare O'Neill has been named locally as the victim of the carjacking&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A new mum screamed for her baby after thieves carjacked her Audi with her four-week-old daughter on the backseat.  The two thugs dragged the mum, named locally as Clare O'Neill, out of her Audi S3 before fleeing the scene in Acocks Green, Birmingham. The baby was dumped at a nearby health centre - still in her booster seat - before the carjackers fled. Ms O'Neill, now recovering in hospital, cried My baby! My baby! as stunned neighbours in the cul-de-sac came out to see what the commotion was. Ms O'Neill's aunt confirmed her niece was the victim of the terrifying incident and said she was still recovering in hospital after being reunited with her daughter.  Neighbour Anjana Chavda, 66, a civil servant, said: I thought they were just kids screaming. I went to my back bedroom window straight away. I saw a lady being dragged by the car. She was holding on to the car as it went down the street. She was clinging on with all her might but she lost her grip. I went into the front window and saw this car going down very fast. It was horrific. West Midlands Police have confirmed the pair have since been reunited after the two suspects launched their attack when she pulled up on her driveway. The force said as Ms O'Neill struggled to get her child out of the grey Audi A3, the pair drove off injuring her in the process. Officers from across the city started a frantic search for the baby and 45 minutes later an ambulance crew at Small Heath Health Centre less than four miles away found the youngster safe and well and still in her car seat.  Force Incident Manager Chief Inspector Tony Cole said: Our primary concern was the safe return of this young child and dozens of officers, including specialist resources, were drafted into the search, which I am so pleased has resulted in her safe return. We are still determined to trace the offenders who have put this mother through a 45 minute nightmare that she will never forget. story: NewsBoy, 15, knocked unconscious by rugby league star because he thought he had bullied his sonWARNING - GRAPHIC CONTENT: Vila Matautia walked free from court after receiving a seven-month prison sentence, suspended for 18 months&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNeil Docking21:11, 19 JUL 2018NewsVila Matautia outside Liverpool Crown Court (Image: LIVERPOOL ECHO)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShocking images show a teenage boy covered in blood after he was battered by an ex pro Rugby League who claimed he had bullied his son. Vila Matautia, 48, knocked Cole Olverson, 15, unconscious and broke his nose, leaving him covered in blood.  The ex-Samoan international admitted repeatedly punching the child, in an assault causing actual bodily harm, reports the Liverpool Echo .  But he said he battered Cole, at the time a year 11 school pupil, because he bullied his son, who was in year eight. Matautia walked free from court today after receiving a seven-month prison sentence, suspended for 18 months.  Judge Steven Everett said it was important Cole was not criticised in any way, as there was no direct evidence of bullying. He said: I'm quite prepared to accept that you genuinely believed your son had been bullied and that either the complainant Cole Olverson or one of his friends was the person who had bulled your son. I'm quite prepared to accept that because from what I've heard about you, you wouldn't have carried out this attack unless there was this genuine belief. But the first thing it is important to say, whether there was this genuine belief or not, is this isn't the way to deal with things.  You don't take the law into your own hands, which is what you did. You're a strong powerful man. He is a 15-year-old boy. It was inevitable who was going to come out the worse and that is what happened. You repeatedly punched him to the face. I hope you've seen those injuries and seen what you did to that boy. Cole was stood with friends behind the Golden Lion pub in Church Road, Rainford at around 4.35pm, on December 4 last year. Liverpool Crown Court heard he received a Snapchat message from Matautia's son, asking where he was, but did not respond. Matautia then walked down the side of the pub towards him and Cole, who did not know who he was, asked are you alright?  The boy said he was knocked unconscious and when he came to, was aware Matautia had hit him around five more times. He said Matautia stood over him and said you're a bully and when asked why, replied: If I find you've done anything again, I will cut you. Matautia got out his phone as if to take a photo of the boy lying on the ground. His son was also spotted in the area. Cole suffered a fractured nasal bone, a cut to his nose, plus bruising to his forehead, left cheek and jaw. He still struggles with breathing. Matautia, of Laurel Road, St Helens, was arrested but lied to police during his first interview, claiming he wasn't at the scene. His mobile phone showed he was and when interviewed again, he said he went there to speak to the boys about bullying.  He claimed another boy pulled a knife on him, that he hit it out of the male's hand and then punched Cole once, in self-defence. Matautia was part of the Saints side which won Super League, Challenge Cup and World Club Challenge honours in the 1990s and 2000s. Tom Watson, defending, said the prop forward, who has a caution for battery in March 2002, led a rather exemplary life. He said he was sorry, adding: He feels a deep sense of shame and quite frankly, he also feels a deep sense of embarrassment. He is not normally a person who would behave in this way. He knows as well as distressing and upsetting for this young man, he has made a spectacle of himself. That is not the way this man ordinarily lives his life and it's not the way he is going to behave in the future.  A probation report assessed Matautia, who now works as a self-employed plasterer, as having a low risk of re-offending. Judge Everett handed him a 10-day rehabilitation activity requirement and an indefinite restraining order. He ordered him to pay &pound1,000 in compensation to Cole and &pound400 towards prosecution costs. After the hearing, Cole's mum, Joanne Olverson, 35, told the ECHO she was disappointed with the sentence and felt Matautia got away with it. Speaking outside of court, she said Cole fell out with Matautia's son over a minor disagreement, but denied he ever bullied him. She said her friend found Cole, now 16, covered in blood and unable to walk, with his face such a mess you wouldn't recognise him.  Mrs Olverson said: There is no justification for knocking a child unconscious. Taking a photo of him lying on the floor, that to me was the sickening thing, and threatening to cut him. He's a good lad and he's never been in trouble. He had four months off school when his dad died. When he went back to school, it was only part time. After this happened, he was doing a mechanics apprenticeship, he had to stop that and was suffering anxiety and depression.
